content: OK all you out there that claim to know it all. Lets see how smart you really are. All you college educated folks don't be too surprised if some one with an 8th grade education is smarter than you are. Remember when grandparents and great-grandparents stated that they only had an 8th grade education? Well, check this out. Could any of us have passed the 8th grade in 1895? This is the eighth-grade final exam from 1895 in Salina , Kansas , USA . It was taken from the original document on file at the Smokey Valley Genealogical Society and Library in Salina , KS , and reprinted by the Salina Journal. 8th Grade Final Exam: Salina, KS, 1895 Grammar (Time, one hour) 1. Give nine rules for the use of capital letters. 2. Name the parts of speech and define those that have no modifications. 3. Define verse, stanza and paragraph 4. What are the principal parts of a verb? Give principal parts of "lie", "play", and "run." 5. Define case; illustrate each case. 6. What is punctuation? Give rules for principal marks of punctuation. 7 - 10. Write a composition of about 150 words and show therein that you understand the practical use of the rules of grammar. Arithmetic (Time, 65 minutes) 1. Name and define the Fundamental Rules of Arithmetic. 2. A wagon box is 2 ft. deep, 10 feet long, and 3 ft. wide. How many bushels of wheat will it hold? 3. If a load of wheat weighs 3942 lbs., what is it worth at 50cts/bushel, deducting 1050 lbs. for tare? 4. District No 33 has a valuation of $35,000. What is the necessary levy to carry on a school seven months at $50 per month, and have $104 for incidentals? 5. Find the cost of 6720 lbs. coal at $6.00 per ton. 6. Find the interest of $512.60 for 8 months and 18 days at 7 percent. 7. What is the cost of 40 boards 12 inches wide and 16 ft. long at $20 per meter? 8. Find bank discount on $300 for 90 days (no grace) at 10 percent. 9. What is the cost of a square farm at $15 per acre, the distance of which is 640 rods? 10. Write a Bank Check, a Promissory Note, and a Receipt U.S. History (Time, 45 minutes) 1. Give the epochs into which U.S. History is divided 2. Give an account of the discovery of America by Columbus . 3. Relate the causes and results of the Revolutionary War. 4. Show the territorial growth of the United States . 5. Tell what you can of the history of Kansas . 6. Describe three of the most prominent battles of the Rebellion. 7. Who were the following: Morse, Whitney, Fulton, Bell, Lincoln, Penn, and Howe? 8. Name events connected with the following dates: 1607, 1620, 1800, 1849, and 1865. Orthography (Time, one hour) (Do we even know what this is???) 1. What is meant by the following: alphabet, phonetic, orthography, etymology, and syllabication. 2. What are elementary sounds? How classified? 3. What are the following, and give examples of each: trigraph, sub vocal, diphthong, cognate letters, and lingual. 4. Give four substitutes for caret 'u.' (HUH?) 5. Give two rules for spelling words with final 'e.' Name two exceptions under each rule. 6. Give two uses of silent letters in spelling. Illustrate each. 7. Define the following prefixes and use in connection with a word: bi-, dis-, mis-, pre-, semi-, post-, non-, inter-, mono-, and sup-. 8. Mark diacritically and divide into syllables the following, and name the sign that indicates the sound: card, ball, mercy, sir, odd, cell, rise, blood, fare, last. 9. Use the following correctly in sentences: cite, site, sight, fane, fain, feign, vane, vain, vein, raze, raise, rays. 10. Write 10 words frequently mispronounced and indicate pronunciation by use of diacritical marks and by syllabication. Geography (Time, one hour) 1 What is climate? Upon what does climate depend? 2. How do you account for the extremes of climate in Kansas ? 3. Of what use are rivers? Of what use is the ocean? 4. Describe the mountains of North America 5. Name and describe the following: Monrovia , Odessa , Denver , Manitoba , Hecla , Yukon , St. Helena, Juan Fernandez, Aspinwall and Orinoco . 6. Name and locate the principal trade centers of the U.S. 7. Name all the republics of: Europe and give the capital of each. 8. Why is the Atlantic Coast colder than the Pacific in the same latitude? 9. Describe the process by which the water of the ocean returns to the sources of rivers. 10. Describe the movements of the earth. Give the inclination of the earth. Notice that the exam took FIVE HOURS to complete. Gives the saying "he only had an 8th grade education" a whole new meaning, doesn't it? This also shows you how poor our education system has become... and, NO! I don't have the answers

I don't have the answers You might add to this test: "If you take off from Kennedy Air Port and climb to the altitude of 30,000 feet, fly a westerly direct course at Mach 0.8 with a jet stream speed of 100 knots and a northern wind drift of 30 knots, what would be your actual course and speed, and how long would it take you to reach San Francisco 2200 miles away?" When you have a very limited world of study and knowledge, you can can focus on the minute and trivial. But when the world is vast and limitless, what do you spend your time focusing on?" Much of the linguistics focused on in the beginning of your "eight grade test" is great trivia for college academians to wrangle over in some dim room, but do you think of any of that as you type your responses here? Would it even matter? Much of "English Grammar" is technically wrong anyway, because all the terms come from the old attempts to force Latin Grammar and divisions onto English in ways that really don't apply, because, in verbs for instance, English doesn't change spelling enough. Latin does have six tenses (six changes in the spelling of the verb), but English really only has two: Present and Past (run/ran). English created all its notions of "time/tense" with word combinations of present and past rather than spelling changes: could have been going to go, might have gone, has gone, was gone - - So a great deal of that memorization was time wasted on misinformation. I know this to be true from arguing nose to nose with professors and teaching "English" for 30+ years - - There are some bare-bones Grammar Principles that need to be mastered to communicate effectively: Start a sentence with a capital; end with a period; learn the use of conjunctions, adverbial connectives, and semi-colons; know how adjectives, prepositional phrases, and dependent clauses work, and avoid dangling modifiers, etc.; and so on...up through parallelism, paragraph writing; and the creation of academic papers, epistles, and creative works of quality - - All of which can be contained for the High School student in about a 20 page guide book - - My point is that today, there is such a vast amount of things the average 8th Grader is supposed to know a great deal about that it is mind-boggling... Microbes and to Space Travel...Islamic Fundamentalism to Nuclear War...Financial Responsibility to Global Warming - - What should he or his teachers focus on?!?!? This is the eighth-grade final exam from 1895 in Salina , Kansas , USA . It was taken from the original document on file at the Smokey Valley Genealogical Society and Library in Salina , KS , and reprinted by the Salina Journal. 8th Grade Final Exam: Salina, KS, 1895 Grammar (Time, one hour) 1. Give nine rules for the use of capital letters. 2. Name the parts of speech and define those that have no modifications. 3. Define verse, stanza and paragraph 4. What are the principal parts of a verb? Give principal parts of "lie", "play", and "run." 5. Define case; illustrate each case. 6. What is punctuation? Give rules for principal marks of punctuation. 7 - 10. Write a composition of about 150 words and show therein that you understand the practical use of the rules of grammar. Arithmetic (Time, 65 minutes) 1. Name and define the Fundamental Rules of Arithmetic. 2. A wagon box is 2 ft. deep, 10 feet long, and 3 ft. wide. How many bushels of wheat will it hold? 3. If a load of wheat weighs 3942 lbs., what is it worth at 50cts/bushel, deducting 1050 lbs. for tare? 4. District No 33 has a valuation of $35,000. What is the necessary levy to carry on a school seven months at $50 per month, and have $104 for incidentals? 5. Find the cost of 6720 lbs. coal at $6.00 per ton. 6. Find the interest of $512.60 for 8 months and 18 days at 7 percent. 7. What is the cost of 40 boards 12 inches wide and 16 ft. long at $20 per meter? 8. Find bank discount on $300 for 90 days (no grace) at 10 percent. 9. What is the cost of a square farm at $15 per acre, the distance of which is 640 rods? 10. Write a Bank Check, a Promissory Note, and a Receipt U.S. History (Time, 45 minutes) 1. Give the epochs into which U.S. History is divided 2. Give an account of the discovery of America by Columbus . 3. Relate the causes and results of the Revolutionary War. 4. Show the territorial growth of the United States . 5. Tell what you can of the history of Kansas . 6. Describe three of the most prominent battles of the Rebellion. 7. Who were the following: Morse, Whitney, Fulton, Bell, Lincoln, Penn, and Howe? 8. Name events connected with the following dates: 1607, 1620, 1800, 1849, and 1865. Orthography (Time, one hour) (Do we even know what this is???) 1. What is meant by the following: alphabet, phonetic, orthography, etymology, and syllabication. 2. What are elementary sounds? How classified? 3. What are the following, and give examples of each: trigraph, sub vocal, diphthong, cognate letters, and lingual. 4. Give four substitutes for caret 'u.' (HUH?) 5. Give two rules for spelling words with final 'e.' Name two exceptions under each rule. 6. Give two uses of silent letters in spelling. Illustrate each. 7. Define the following prefixes and use in connection with a word: bi-, dis-, mis-, pre-, semi-, post-, non-, inter-, mono-, and sup-. 8. Mark diacritically and divide into syllables the following, and name the sign that indicates the sound: card, ball, mercy, sir, odd, cell, rise, blood, fare, last. 9. Use the following correctly in sentences: cite, site, sight, fane, fain, feign, vane, vain, vein, raze, raise, rays. 10. Write 10 words frequently mispronounced and indicate pronunciation by use of diacritical marks and by syllabication. Geography (Time, one hour) 1 What is climate? Upon what does climate depend? 2. How do you account for the extremes of climate in Kansas ? 3. Of what use are rivers? Of what use is the ocean? 4. Describe the mountains of North America 5. Name and describe the following: Monrovia , Odessa , Denver , Manitoba , Hecla , Yukon , St. Helena, Juan Fernandez, Aspinwall and Orinoco . 6. Name and locate the principal trade centers of the U.S. 7. Name all the republics of: Europe and give the capital of each. 8. Why is the Atlantic Coast colder than the Pacific in the same latitude? 9. Describe the process by which the water of the ocean returns to the sources of rivers. 10. Describe the movements of the earth. Give the inclination of the earth. Notice that the exam took FIVE HOURS to complete. This is the eighth-grade final exam from 1895 in Salina , Kansas , USA . It was taken from the original document on file at the Smokey Valley Genealogical Society and Library in Salina , KS , and reprinted by the Salina Journal. 8th Grade Final Exam: Salina, KS, 1895 Grammar (Time, one hour) 1. Give nine rules for the use of capital letters. 2. Name the parts of speech and define those that have no modifications. 3. Define verse, stanza and paragraph 4. What are the principal parts of a verb? Give principal parts of "lie", "play", and "run." 5. Define case; illustrate each case. 6. What is punctuation? Give rules for principal marks of punctuation. 7 - 10. Write a composition of about 150 words and show therein that you understand the practical use of the rules of grammar. Arithmetic (Time, 65 minutes) 1. Name and define the Fundamental Rules of Arithmetic. 2. A wagon box is 2 ft. deep, 10 feet long, and 3 ft. wide. How many bushels of wheat will it hold? 3. If a load of wheat weighs 3942 lbs., what is it worth at 50cts/bushel, deducting 1050 lbs. for tare? 4. District No 33 has a valuation of $35,000. What is the necessary levy to carry on a school seven months at $50 per month, and have $104 for incidentals? 5. Find the cost of 6720 lbs. coal at $6.00 per ton. 6. Find the interest of $512.60 for 8 months and 18 days at 7 percent. 7. What is the cost of 40 boards 12 inches wide and 16 ft. long at $20 per meter? 8. Find bank discount on $300 for 90 days (no grace) at 10 percent. 9. What is the cost of a square farm at $15 per acre, the distance of which is 640 rods? 10. Write a Bank Check, a Promissory Note, and a Receipt U.S. History (Time, 45 minutes) 1. Give the epochs into which U.S. History is divided 2. Give an account of the discovery of America by Columbus . 3. Relate the causes and results of the Revolutionary War. 4. Show the territorial growth of the United States . 5. Tell what you can of the history of Kansas . 6. Describe three of the most prominent battles of the Rebellion. 7. Who were the following: Morse, Whitney, Fulton, Bell, Lincoln, Penn, and Howe? 8. Name events connected with the following dates: 1607, 1620, 1800, 1849, and 1865. Orthography (Time, one hour) (Do we even know what this is???) 1. What is meant by the following: alphabet, phonetic, orthography, etymology, and syllabication. 2. What are elementary sounds? How classified? 3. What are the following, and give examples of each: trigraph, sub vocal, diphthong, cognate letters, and lingual. 4. Give four substitutes for caret 'u.' (HUH?) 5. Give two rules for spelling words with final 'e.' Name two exceptions under each rule. 6. Give two uses of silent letters in spelling. Illustrate each. 7. Define the following prefixes and use in connection with a word: bi-, dis-, mis-, pre-, semi-, post-, non-, inter-, mono-, and sup-. 8. Mark diacritically and divide into syllables the following, and name the sign that indicates the sound: card, ball, mercy, sir, odd, cell, rise, blood, fare, last. 9. Use the following correctly in sentences: cite, site, sight, fane, fain, feign, vane, vain, vein, raze, raise, rays. 10. Write 10 words frequently mispronounced and indicate pronunciation by use of diacritical marks and by syllabication. Geography (Time, one hour) 1 What is climate? Upon what does climate depend? 2. How do you account for the extremes of climate in Kansas ? 3. Of what use are rivers? Of what use is the ocean? 4. Describe the mountains of North America 5. Name and describe the following: Monrovia , Odessa , Denver , Manitoba , Hecla , Yukon , St. Helena, Juan Fernandez, Aspinwall and Orinoco . 6. Name and locate the principal trade centers of the U.S. 7. Name all the republics of: Europe and give the capital of each. 8. Latin does have six tenses (six changes in the spelling of the verb), but English really only has two: Present and Past (run/ran). English created all its notions of "time/tense" with word combinations of present and past rather than spelling changes: could have been going to go, might have gone, has gone, was gone - - So a great deal of that memorization was time wasted on misinformation. content: quote: Oh, GWG, you forgot the future tense, it is known to exist and has been used mate. Not in English. Try respelling "run" to mean future. True "Tense" is a spelling change (sit/sat) not a notional (idea) change. The ONLY way you can obtain the notion/idea of "future tense" in English is two combine to "present tense" verbs: will (present) run (present) = will run (notion of future, but not a true tense/spelling change). Yup, I've argued those concepts with college professors, and I'm right. When "English" (Angle/Saxon German)went through its "slave period" after the 1066 conquest of Briton by the French-Speaking Normans until about 1300, only the uneducated, lower class peasants spoke it as a vulgar (common) language. The upper class spoke/wrote French and Latin. Because "Anglish" was not written or studied, it went through enormous modifications, including dropping of rigorous spelling changes for tense/time changes. They gave way to syntax (word order - subject/verb/object) and word combination changes (verb phrases, prepositional phrases, dependent clause phrases) which could be learned/understood/memorized by ear - as in singing of songs or reciting poems - - This streamlined Anglish/English oral grammar a great deal, but when England separated from Europe as a Power under Henry the VIII, suddenly there was an over-weaning need to put English on the same level of the Great Languages of Europe to make England Great! So, Latin Grammar was superimposed, even though it didn't fit. Dictionaries were attempted and finally created (Samuel Johnson). And English/England became the Empire of the World - but the language had three major problems: It was not an original language, but actually a combination of German, French, and Latin. All their Grammars and spellings are floating around all over in it, creating one problem after another (Celtic forms having been completely ignored). Lastly, it is an eclectic language that will drink up whatever wanders past (canoe, tomato, kung fu, byte). - - So what do we do? Do what we do best - play it by ear!! By the way, computers can learn English faster than other languages, because of the simple, mathematical word-order grammar: noun+verb+noun/adjective/adverb=sentence - Sam drives truck; Sam is sleepy; Sam drives poorly. The peasant simplification "Anglish" is logical... Wandering and Wondering

content: GWG, I do believe sentient distributed artificial intelligences are likely to exist in the future. Mobile consciousnesses capable of copying themselves at will through cyberspace. Anyone with, say, an earpiece could interact with one. If they are created we will have to ask ourselves some serious questions - what role shall they play in our societies. As virtual intelligences the only way they might be capable of appearing to us are through millions of microrobots capable of manipulating static fields and light to create a three dimensional figure. They might be so alien to us we might be forced to create their own "construct" and isolate them within it, for their protection as well as our own. As far as knowledge perhaps we might be able to encode knowledge within an RNA structure in the future. Take an RNA pill, know all there is to know about grammar, or arithmetic, or piloting an F-22. The knowledge can appear as a memory that's always been there.
